Yola_(singer):
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2022}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Yola | caption = Yola in 2019 | birth_name = Yolanda Claire Quartey{{Cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/arts/music/yola-grammys.html|title=Behind a 'Best New Artist' Nod: Yola's 20 Years of Experience|date=22 January 2020|website=The New York Times|access-date=13 August 2021}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1983|07|31|df=y}} | birth_place = Bristol, England | genre = {{flatlist| * [[Country soul]] * [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] * [[Americana (music)|Americana]] }} | label = Easy Eye Sound | website = {{URL|https://iamyola.com}} | image = Yola at Codfish Hollow, Maquoketa, September 20th 2019.jpg }} '''Yolanda Claire Quartey''' (born 31 July 1983), known professionally as '''Yola''' or '''Yola Carter''', is an English singer-songwriter, musician, and actress. Her debut studio album ''[[Walk Through Fire (Yola album)|Walk Through Fire]]'' (2019) received critical acclaim and earned her four [[Grammy Award]] nominations, including [[Grammy Award for Best New Artist|Best New Artist]]. Her follow-up, ''[[Stand for Myself]]'' (2021), received similar acclaim and earned her two more Grammy nominations. Yola made her acting debut in 2022, portraying "the Godmother of rock and roll" [[Sister Rosetta Tharpe]] in [[Baz Luhrman]]'s biopic ''[[Elvis (2022 film)|Elvis]]'', and later made her [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] debut in 2024 when she began playing [[Persephone]] in [[Anaïs Mitchell]]'s musical ''[[Hadestown]]''. ==Early and personal life== Yola was born in [[Bristol]], England.{{cite web | url=https://amp.theguardian.com/music/2019/feb/21/yola-from-down-and-out-in-london-to-nashvilles-country-soul-star | title=Yola: From down and out in London to Nashville's country soul star | Music | the Guardian }} Her family tried to discourage her from music at a young age, as they thought it was an unrealistic career option.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-bristol-50494723|title=Grammy nominee's mum 'banned her from music'|date=21 November 2019|website=Bbc.co.uk}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.popmatters.com/yola-walk-through-fire-review-2629672456.html |title=Yola's Vocals and Songwriting Are Showcased on Her Strong Debut 'Walk Through Fire' |date=22 February 2019 |website=Popmatters.com |access-date=13 May 2019}} When Yola was just under 2 her father left her and her mother behind.{{Cite web |date=2019-07-11 |title=Yola on her journey from homelessness and poverty to writing an album with Dan Auerbach |url=https://guitar.com/features/interviews/yola-yolanda-quartey-dan-auerbach/ |access-date=2022-04-09 |website=Guitar.com {{!}} All Things Guitar |language=en-GB}} A single parent struggling to stay afloat, her mother was against Yola's dream to be a singer. It wasn't until Yola went to grammar school she had her first taste of freedom and started to pursue music. She later went to university in London and used her student loan to stay afloat while making music. She ended up becoming a university drop out and was evicted due to being unable to pay her rent. Yola was homeless for six months in her 20's and spent a week begging on the streets before getting enough money to travel back to Bristol.{{cite news |title=Yola on The Adam Buxton Podcast |url=https://www.adam-buxton.co.uk/podcasts/wmcgmfe7zj7chps-89fa4-2e48e-rwzy8-824b8-4mdjd-2hcs8-chrb2-7y8jj-5pcse-2wtsh-cz8zd-e3cdy-g68s7-3dezn-7k5mw-y739l-p75rr-jr8a7-7akgj-l4zms-mbmhm-486s5-jg45z-n3dba-3g2sh-3bme9 |access-date=June 23, 2022 |work=[[The Adam Buxton Podcast]] |date=June 19, 2022}} ==Career== Under her given name Yolanda Quartey, Yola first Yola has performed as a guest vocalist and occasional songwriter for British musical acts like, [[Duke Dumont]], [[Bugz In The Attic]], [[Chase & Status]] and [[Sub Focus]],{{Cite news|last=Pareles|first=Jon|date=2020-01-22|title=Behind a 'Best New Artist' Nod: Yola's 20 Years of Experience|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/22/arts/music/yola-grammys.html|access-date=2021-12-14|issn=0362-4331}} [[Massive Attack]],{{Cite web|title=Yola's Journey From the Darkness of Massive Attack to Her Harmonious Debut|url=https://www.allmusic.com/blog/post/yola-interview|access-date=2021-12-14|website=AllMusic|language=en}} [[Bugz in the Attic]],{{Cite news|last=Gordon|first=Jeremy|date=2021-07-25|title=After Two Decades in Music, Yola Expands Her Powers|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/25/arts/music/yola-stand-for-myself.html|access-date=2021-12-14|issn=0362-4331}} [[Ginger Wildheart]],{{Cite web|last=Williams|first=Kathryn|date=2019-06-04|title=Who is supporting The Killers at Cardiff Castle?|url=https://www.walesonline.co.uk/whats-on/music-nightlife-news/the-killers-cardiff-castle-support-16377750|access-date=2021-12-14|website=WalesOnline|language=en}} and [[Duke Dumont]].{{Cite news|date=2019-12-14|title=Yola: From 'house screamer' to four-time Grammy nominee|language=en-GB|work=BBC News|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/newsbeat-50746433|access-date=2021-12-14}} Yola decided to launch a solo career after the death of her mother in 2013. She released her first solo EP, ''Orphan Offering'', in 2016. In February 2019, she released her debut album ''[[Walk Through Fire (Yola album)|Walk Through Fire]]'' on [[Dan Auerbach]]'s Easy Eye Sound label, to much acclaim.{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/yola-artist-you-need-to-know-780854/ |title=Yola's Fight for Roots-Rock Freedom |first1=Jonathan |last1=Bernstein|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=19 January 2019}}{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2019/feb/21/yola-from-down-and-out-in-london-to-nashvilles-country-soul-star |title=Yola: from down and out in London to Nashville's country soul star |first=Emma |last=John |date=21 February 2019 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]]}}{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/walk-through-fire-by-yola-review-across-the-great-divide-11551127972 |title='Walk Through Fire' by Yola Review: Across the Great Divide |first=Barry |last=Mazor |date=25 February 2019 |newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]]}} The album title references a fire which damaged Yola's home and she escaped.{{Cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/2019/02/14/693862024/first-listen-yola-walk-through-fire |title=On Her Mighty Debut, Yola Pushes Through To 'Walk Through Fire' |website=Npr.org|access-date=13 May 2019}} [[AllMusic]] called the album "an extraordinary record, one designed to be part of a grand musical tradition, and it contains enough emotion and imagination to earn its place within that lineage."{{cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/walk-through-fire-mw0003232038 |title=Walk Through Fire – Yola – Songs, Reviews, Credits |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=12 March 2019}} Brittney McKenna of [[NPR Music]]'s First Listen declared, "It's the work of an artist sure to stun audiences for years to come."{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2019/02/14/693862024/first-listen-yola-walk-through-fire|title=On Her Mighty Debut, Yola Pushes Through To 'Walk Through Fire'|website=Npr.org}} ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' stated, "The album is an introduction to a seasoned, major vocalist that stands to be remembered as a breakthrough." ''Walk Through Fire'' was written, recorded and produced at [[Dan Auerbach]]'s Easy Eye Studio in Nashville. Auerbach produced the record and assembled an all-star cast for its creation.{{Cite web|url=https://theboot.com/yola-ride-out-in-the-country-lyrics-information/|title=Story Behind the Song: Yola, 'Ride Out in the Country'|first=Carena|last=Liptak|website=The Boot|date=12 February 2019 }} Most of the songwriting was a collaboration of Yola and Auerbach with contributions from Bobby Wood, [[Pat McLaughlin]] and [[Dan Penn]]. The team of studio musicians included bassist Dave Roe, harmonica player Charlie McCoy along with former members of the Memphis Boys drummer Gene Crisman and Wood on piano. Additional vocals were contributed by [[Vince Gill]], [[Molly Tuttle]], [[Ronnie McCoury]] and [[Stuart Duncan]]. The album was recorded and engineered by M. Allen Parker. Auerbach and Parker also mixed the project.{{Cite web|url=https://circuitsweet.co.uk/2019/02/yola-premieres-video-for-love-all-night-work-all-day-taken-from-forthcoming-album/|title=YOLA PREMIERES VIDEO FOR 'LOVE ALL NIGHT (WORK ALL DAY)' TAKEN FROM FORTHCOMING ALBUM|website=Circuitsweet.co.uk|date=2 February 2019}} In March 2019, Yola made her American television debut on ''[[CBS This Morning]]'''s Saturday Sessions segment, where she played selections from ''Walk Through Fire.''{{Cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/yola-cbs-this-morning-812453/|title=Watch Yola Showcase Debut LP on 'CBS This Morning'|first1=Ilana|last1=Kaplan|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=23 March 2019}} She, alongside [[Sheryl Crow]], contributed to two tracks on the [[The Highwomen (album)|debut album]] by [[The Highwomen]]. Yola made a splash at the [[Newport Folk Festival]] 2019 with ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' proclaiming, "Yola became the single most sought-after voice at this year's festival. She played a triumphant side-stage show, served as an unofficial member of [[The Highwomen]], and added her own vocals to performances by everyone from [[Dolly Parton]] to [[Dawes (band)|Dawes]], who let the fast-rising singer take over for the entirety of their 2009 song "When You Call My Name."{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-live-reviews/newport-folk-fest-2019-recap-864579/|title=Newport Folk Festival 2019: 10 Best Things We Saw|author1=Jonathan Bernstein|author2=Suzy Exposito|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=29 July 2019|access-date=29 January 2020}} According to Glide Magazine, "People came from far and wide to hear Yola sing, either because they were enchanted by her excellent release from earlier this year ''Walk Through Fire'', or because word of mouth had reached them that this was not to be missed."{{cite web |url=https://glidemagazine.com/229257/newport-folk-festival-day-1-showcases-female-prowess-with-yola-kacey-musgraves-highwomen-more-festival-recap/ |title=Archived copy |website=glidemagazine.com |access-date=14 January 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201001081402/https://glidemagazine.com/229257/newport-folk-festival-day-1-showcases-female-prowess-with-yola-kacey-musgraves-highwomen-more-festival-recap/ |archive-date=1 October 2020 |url-status=dead}} ''Walk Through Fire'' generated three Grammy Award nominations. The album was nominated for [[Best Americana Album]] and the track "Faraway Look" was nominated for [[Best American Roots Song]] and [[Best American Roots Performance]]. Additionally, Yola was nominated for [[Best New Artist]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/news/2020-grammy-awards-complete-winners-list|title=2020 GRAMMY Awards: Complete Winners List|date=20 November 2019|website=Grammy.com|access-date=29 January 2020}} In February 2020, ''Variety'' announced that she had been cast to portray [[Sister Rosetta Tharpe]] — "dubbed the Godmother of rock and roll" — in Australian director [[Baz Luhrmann]]s film [[Elvis (2022 film)|Elvis]] on the life of [[Elvis Presley]] set for release in 2022.{{cite news |last1=Kroll |first1=Justin |title=Yola to Play Sister Rosetta Tharpe in Baz Luhrmann's 'Elvis' (EXCLUSIVE) |url=https://variety.com/2020/film/news/yola-elvis-presley-movie-sister-rosetta-tharpe-1203510668/ |access-date=September 21, 2020 |work=Variety |date=February 21, 2020}} In December 2020, she was featured in [[Ringo Starr]]'s single and video "Here's To The Nights", from his 2021 ''[[Zoom In (EP)|Zoom In]]'' EP. In July 2021, Yola released her latest album titled ''[[Stand for Myself]]''.{{Cite web|last=Magazine|first=Guitar Girl|date=2021-04-22|title=Yola announces release of new album 'Stand For Myself' and debuts video for single "Diamond Studded Shoes" - Guitar Girl Magazine|url=https://guitargirlmag.com/news/music-news/yola-announces-release-of-new-album-stand-for-myself-and-debuts-video-for-single-diamond-studded-shoes/,%20https://guitargirlmag.com/news/music-news/yola-announces-release-of-new-album-stand-for-myself-and-debuts-video-for-single-diamond-studded-shoes/|access-date=2021-09-29|language=en-US}} To celebrate the launch of the album, Yola will commence her 2022 Stand For Myself Tour in Boston in February 2022, with opening performances by Jac Ross and Nick Connors; and in Nashville by [[Devon Gilfillian]] and [[Allison Russell]].{{Cite web|date=2021-08-10|title=Yola Announces 2022 'Stand For Myself' U.S. Headlining Tour|url=https://liveforlivemusic.com/news/yola-2022-us-tour-dates/|access-date=2021-09-29|website=L4LM|language=en-US}} On October 8th, 2021, Yola played a sold out show [[Madison Square Garden]] when she opened for [[Chris Stapleton]].{{Cite web|last=|first=|title=Chris Stapleton played Madison Square Garden w/ Marcus King Band & Yola (pics, setlist)|url=https://www.brooklynvegan.com/chris-stapleton-the-marcus-king-band-yola-madison-square-garden-pics/|access-date=2021-12-14|website=BrooklynVegan|language=en}} On July 2, 2024, Yola made her [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] debut in ''[[Hadestown]]'' at the [[Walter Kerr Theater]], playing the role of [[Persephone]].{{Cite web|last=|first=|title=Grammy Nominee Yola Will Make Broadway Debut in Hadestown|url=https://playbill.com/article/grammy-nominee-yola-will-make-broadway-debut-in-hadestown|access-date=2024-05-21|website=[[Playbill]]|language=en}} ==Discography== === Studio albums === {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" border="1" |+ List of studio albums, with selected chart positions and album details ! scope="col" rowspan="2" style="width:12em;"| Title ! scope="col" rowspan="2" style="width:16em;"| Details ! scope="col" colspan="8"| Peak chart positions |- ! scope="col" style="width:3em;font-size:90%;"| [[UK Albums Chart|UK]]
